text: MAUD DOWLEY, (32) an odd, impish little creature, with hu saucers for eyes, is lying on the tall, overgrown grass staring up at the sky, smoking a cigarette. Her fingers a gnarled, her knuckles swollen with arthritis. A shadow repeatedly moves across her face and leaves it. The shadow is from an old swing made of rope and wood, dangling from the branch of a tree. The swing is swaying back and forth. As it slows down, Maud reaches up and giv it another push. She keeps staring at the sky, blowing he smoke towards the sky and watching as it blends into the clouds above. She stares at the clouds curiously, suddenl finding shapes and objects: A bunny rabbit. A steam engin Kittens. AUNT IDA (55), a sturdy, robust woman comes out, carrying mop and bucket. She is wearing an apron and a scarf aroun her head. Her sleeves are rolled up passed her elbows. She's heavily into her spring cleaning. Beads of sweat ru down her forehead. Maud picks herself up from the ground and takes a seat on the swing. Her feet dangling, unable to reach the ground. Ida hurries past Maud, a woman on a mission. The clothesline is filled with sheets, billowing about in the wind. The fence is lined with hooked rugs, out for freshening. Aunt Ida chucks the water from the bucket off to the side of the house. She takes the mop and starts to whack the rugs. Little clouds of dust appear with each wh

Look at that, tsk tsk. The dust is going on the sheets. Ida takes the sheets off the line piling them up in her a Maud chucks her cigarette butt, gets up and starts to hel She takes the armload of sheets from Ida.
I got it. But then Maud gets tangled in a sheet still on the line, stumbles. She drops a sheet.
Maud. I'll have to rewash it now. It's easier if I do it alone, you're too awkward. (CONTINUED)

Ida takes the sheets from her and heads into the house. Maud sits back down on the swing - discouraged. But then, she leans back, stares up at the clouds, as the move swiftly across the sky. The rabbits in the clouds ar almost bunny-hopping their way across the sky. Maud gets up and walks towards the house. As she stands o the veranda, she looks out on the landscape in wonder Then she lights up another cigarette....
Maud sits at the table, while Ida brings her tea and bisc into the austere dining room.
Here you go. Would you like jam?
That'd be nice. As Ida leaves the dining room:
But I can get it myself Aunt Ida. Moments later, she places the jam down in front of her. A Ida fusses around the dining room:
Your brother is coming by tomorrow. Maud looks up, surprised.
Why? Is he taking me back home?
He's moving to Halifax. So he's dropping off a few of your things.

If Charles and his wife are moving to Halifax, the house'll be empty. I can live there and take care of it. Irene says nothing. Maud takes a sip of her hot tea and i slips from her hand, spilling everywhere. (CONTINUED)
Ow.
Stay there, I'll clean it.
I can do it.
I'll clean it. Irene rushes to grab a cloth.

I'll be down in a minute, okay? Her suitcase is on the bed, with her belongings packed ne inside. She struggles to put the last bobby pin in her ha then grabs her belongings, and hurries out of the room.
CHARLES DOWLEY (37), Maud's handsome brother, is leaning against the door frame as Ida brings in his tea.
Take a seat.
I can't stay long.
At least stay for a cup of tea and a bit of cake.
So has she been out, looking for trouble?
So far, no. She keeps to herself. She's been asking to go home.
Did you tell her? (CONTINUED)
Not yet. I thought it best you do it. By now, Maud is standing in the doorway, having overheard the last bit of this conversation. She tries to hide her nervous concern with a smile.
Maud stands awkwardly, shy and nervous in front of her opposing brother.
Hi Charles. Nice to see you. Sizing him up:
Oh my, that's a good jacket you're wearing, it's a good fit. You're always such a spiffy dresser. She smiles at him.
I can't tell the difference between a rag and a ball gown. She chuckles, nervously. Then:
So? You've come to take me home? He shifts on his feet, and says nothing.
What's the big secret?
It's business. Financial matters.
Well, I'm a natural at math. Remember, I used to double check your numbers when you were in school?
I don't have much time, I've got to be going, but I wanted to drop off a few things. (CONTINUED)
He points to a little stack of things: books, photographs and old blanket.
Lordy. You cleared out my room. Why?
Because I sold my house.
What house. Our house?
It was my house. Mom left it to me. I sold it and I'm moving to Halifax with the band. Maud is taken aback.
You can't sell that house. I woulda moved back there. I'd be more than happy to have my own place, I'd look after it --
You can't look after yourself, let alone a house, and a yard, and bills.
I'd get a job, or something.
Job doing what?
I don't know, something.
I'm sorry Maud. It's gone. He smiles tightly, then heads towards the door. Maud foll him.
Did you spend all the money they left behind? Because I haven't seen any of that either.
They didn't leave it for you Maud. (CONTINUED)
We both know mother would have expected you to look after me.
She also would have expected you to behave like a decent girl. But you didn't. He keeps going towards the door.
Wait. Charles.
Maud, come get your tea.
Charles! He turns to her.
Good-bye sister. He leaves. Maud watches out the door, a little stunned. Ida sees she is upset.
He's a busy man, Maud. Maud fights back tears.
Yeah. I know. Maud takes the package and goes back into her room.

Maud is sitting on the swing, looking through the content of the package of her things: photos, trinkets. A photogr of her as a little girl with her cat Fluffy. Some old pai brushes and paints. Melancholy.

Maud is still sitting on the edge of her bed, the lights off. She's still waiting, waiting. She watches through th crack in the bottom of her bedroom door as the SHADOW of Aunt Ida's footsteps pass by her room. (CONTINUED)
Seconds later, the light from the hallway is turned off, the CLICK of a bedroom door being shut. (CONTINUED)
Moments later, Maud gets up and gently opens her bedroom door and sneaks out.

Music pours out of the jazz club as Maud approaches, tryi to contain her excitment. She smiles at a couple who gigg their way out of the club, arms around each other. Maud gathers her nerve and heads inside.

Inside a jazz club, filled with people, the flame on a cigarette illuminates a dark corner... It is Maud, puffing on a cigarette, hiding from the crowd her eyes scouring the room. She has become an expert at being inconspicuous. She smokes with one hand, and with t other she fiddles with her sweater, pulling it up over he chin as she sways to the music. She spots a couple dancing. Studies them for a bit. She looks to another couple sitting at a table, talking intimately. She scours the room. Her eyes land on a group of women. She studies them with quiet admiration as they laugh. She takes note of one woman, DINA SHEA who is obviously pregnant. As she makes her way toward them, she bumps into a_ short, stubby, and bald MAN. Maud sees him, and her face lights up.
Not sure who was gonna knock over who. (quickly searching for what to say next) Mmmmm. You smell like turkey supper. In a good way. (giggles. ) He tries to make his way around her, but she stops him.
I love this music. Gets my feet going like a couple a hammers. He shoves her aside, annoyed.
Christ, get out of my way. Who let you in here? He walks around her. She watches him for a moment, feelin the sting. But then moves on, with a hopeful determinatio (CONTINUED)

With the band now on break, Maud maneuvers her way throug the dark club. She is smaller than everyone else in the room, and mostly goes unnoticed. She's feeling discourage (CONTINUED)
She is about to give up and go home, until she sees Dina, the pregnant woman, sitting on a bar stool by herself. Ma sidles up next to her.
Bet you're seven months. Maud smiles at the woman. She's very attractive, even tho she's tired. She's smoking a cigarette.
Have you started nesting? Getting your house all fixed up nice and cozy?
Yeah, a little. Maud smiles, looking somewhat envious.
If you're looking to hire a sitter, I'm looking for work. Dina smiles politely.
We won't be hiring a sitter.
No harm in asking. Awkward silence for a beat.
Not often you sees a lady in your condition out at night.
Yeah, well, my old man is the guy with the trumpet, I like to make sure he gets home alright, if you know what I mean. Maud smiles and leans in.
You love it when it kicks? Fluttering like a fish in a bowl. Maud stares at the woman's belly. (CONTINUED)
The heartburn, that's no fun. And the trips to the bathroom. Maud laughs to herself - as if remembering. The woman isn sure how to take Maud.
Oh my, worth it though. Since Maud isn't going away, the woman finally engages.
How old is your baby?
Oh, I don't have a baby. The woman is surprised.
Died at birth.
Sorry.
I didn't see her, but they told me she was really deformed. Sad. Then she looks at Dina, who is mid-puff of a cigarette, somewhat disinterested. Maud can't resist:
Always worried it was cuz I smoked. Dina stops inhaling.
Prob'ly wasn't. Still, you never know. Dina hands her cigarette to Maud. Maud takes it, takes a big inhale. She smiles at the woman.

(referring to the cigarette) Thanks.  10 11 10. INT. AUNT IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALL - NIGHT 10 Maud sneaks her way back to her room, tip toeing up the stairs, carefully trying not to make noise. All the light are off in the house. But as she arrives at the top -- Aunt Ida is standing there. A stern look on her face.
You better not tell me you were out at that club.
I wasn't going to tell you that.
Where were you?
I was at the club. But I wasn't gonna tell you. She smiles. Ida is pissed.
I'm sorry, I couldn't sleep.
You get in trouble again, I'm tossing you out on your duff. Do you understand me?
I'm only looking to meet friends.
That's what you said last time, and look where that got you. In your room. Maud keeps her head down and walks to her room.

I'll do it later.
Let me do it, I'll take the wagon.
Fine, fine. (to the women) Sorry about that. Maud walks out the door.  12 13 12.

As she passes by one house, she admires a family playing with their LITTLE GIRL in a pink dress. She smiles to her as the little girl squeals over something. She continues on, and gets many strange looks from people the street, but she does her best to ignore them.
Maud walks into the general store, her wagon left outside She immediately heads towards the aisles. Her eyes pour over the shelves. MR. MCDOUGAL, the storekeeper, nods at her.
Can I help you with something Miss Dowley?

I know. I like to look at the cans. All the different colours. It's pretty. She smiles at him - he gives an awkward smile back, not knowing how to take her. As Maud walks through the aisles, the bell on the door ri as someone else enters the store. Maud continues to study the shelves.

Am I an idiot? I want to put upa sign. A whadayacall. I need you to write it. Everett hands him a square of paper. The store keeper loo at him skeptically for a moment, then takes up a pen. Eve dictates.

Sense of humour?

You really need a housekeeper at that little house?

What does size got to do with anything? You don't got that big of a store, and you got three or four people works here. I need a hand, I need a hand. Everett takes the note and heads toward the back of the s As he goes, MAUD tip toes along to continue to observe. (CONTINUED)
